docs.lead_paragraph: Cancer researchers are just beginning to understand the ramifications of the fundamental discoveries behind the 2015 Nobel Prizes in Chemistry, which were awarded on Wednesday to three scientists for explaining how cells repair mistakes in DNA that occur when cells divide.

headline.main: Nobel Discoveries on DNA Repair Now Fuelling Cancer Drug Research
headline.print_headline: Nobel Discoveries on DNA Repair Now Fuelling Cancer Drug Research

docs.lead_paragraph: The time could not have been more hostile for Chinese scientists. Research came to a virtual halt and intellectuals were routinely persecuted. But Tu Youyou, then a 39-year-old researcher, was summoned to join a secretive military project during the Cultural Revolution to find a cure for malaria for soldiers in North Vietnam.

headline.main: AP Interview: Secret Project Wins Chinese Scientist a Nobel
headline.print_headline: AP Interview: Secret Project Wins Chinese Scientist a Nobel

docs.lead_paragraph: Dr. Tu was awarded the prize, shared with two other scientists, on Monday for the discovery of a drug that is now part of standard regimens to fight malaria.

headline.main: Answering an Appeal by Mao Led Tu Youyou, a Chinese Scientist, to a Nobel Prize

docs.snippet: Dr. Tu was awarded the prize, shared with two other scientists, on Monday for the discovery of a drug that is now part of standard regimens to fight malaria.

byline.contributor: Chris Buckley contributed reporting, and Mia Li contributed research.

headline.main: Some Surprise, and Affirmation, in China After Tu Youyou Receives Nobel Prize

docs.abstract: Throughout the hubbub, Dr. Tu has said very little. “There was no particular feeling,” she said. “It was a bit of a surprise, but not much of one.”
docs.snippet: Throughout the hubbub, Dr. Tu has said very little. “There was no particular feeling,” she said. “It was a bit of a surprise, but not much of one.”

docs.lead_paragraph: For decades, China has yearned for a Nobel Prize in science. Now, a little-known researcher who helped develop a malaria medicine in a secret military project to assist Vietnam in its war against the U.S. has finally won Beijing that honor.

headline.main: China Wins Long-Sought Nobel Prize in One of the Sciences
headline.print_headline: China Wins Long-Sought Nobel Prize in One of the Sciences

docs.snippet: For decades, China has yearned for a Nobel Prize in science. Now, a little-known researcher who helped develop a malaria medicine in a secret military project to assist Vietnam in its war against the U.S. has finally won Beijing that honor.

docs.lead_paragraph: William Campbell of Drew University, Satoshi Omura of Kitasato University and Youyou Tu of the China Academy of Chinese Medical Sciences won the award.

headline.main: Nobel Prize in Medicine Awarded to 3 Scientists for Parasite-Fighting Therapies
headline.print_headline: 3 Share Nobel for Work on Treatment of ‘Devastating’ Parasitic Diseases

docs.abstract: Scientists William C Campbell, Satoshi Omura and Tu Youyou are jointly awarded Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine for their work on treatment of parasitic diseases; Drs Campbell and Omura, who share one-half of $960,000 award, collaborated on remedy for onchocerciasis, or river blindness, while Dr Tu, who won other half, drew on Chinese medicine to develop drug to combat malaria.
docs.snippet: William Campbell of Drew University, Satoshi Omura of Kitasato University and Youyou Tu of the China Academy of Chinese Medical Sciences won the award.

byline.contributor: Jane Perlez contributed reporting from Beijing, and Jonathan Soble from Tokyo.

headline.main: Chiropractic Care Grows, and Gains Acceptance

docs.abstract: More and more doctors agree that such treatment can help ease back pain, and while all doubts have not been swept away, the author gave it a try.

docs.lead_paragraph: Three scientists from Japan, China and Ireland whose discoveries led to the development of potent new drugs against parasitic diseases including malaria and elephantiasis won the Nobel Prize for Medicine on Monday.

headline.main: Beating Parasites Wins Three Scientists Nobel Prize for Medicine
headline.print_headline: Beating Parasites Wins Three Scientists Nobel Prize for Medicine

docs.snippet: Three scientists from Japan, China and Ireland whose discoveries led to the development of potent new drugs against parasitic diseases including malaria and elephantiasis won the Nobel Prize for Medicine on Monday.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Nobel prize in medicine went Monday to three scientists hailed as "heroes in the truest sense of the word" for saving millions of lives with the creation of the world's leading malaria-fighting drug and another that has nearly wiped out two devastating tropical diseases.

headline.main: 3 Share Nobel Medicine Prize for Tropical Disease Drugs
